1.brief: properly, instrumental music; by implication, a poem set to notes
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, perhaps to separate, i.e. distinguish (literally or figuratively); by implication, to be (causatively, make) great, difficult, wonderful
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
properly, to be open, wide or free, i.e. (by implication) to be safe; causatively, to free or succor
the right hand or side (leg, eye) of a person or other object (as the stronger and more dexterous); locally, the south
the arm (as stretched out), or (of animals) the foreleg; figuratively, force
a sacred place or thing; rarely abstract, sanctity

2.brief: to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
something saved, i.e. (abstractly) deliverance; hence, aid, victory, prosperity
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
to denude (especially in a disgraceful sense); by implication, to exile (captives being usually stripped); figuratively, to reveal
rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)

3.brief: properly, to mark (so as to be recognized), i.e. to remember; by implication, to mention;  to be male
kindness; by implication (towards God) piety; rarely (by opposition) reproof, or (subject.) beauty
literally firmness; figuratively security; morally fidelity
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
cessation, i.e. an end (especially of the earth); often used adverb, no further; also the ankle (in the dual), as being the extremity of the leg or foot
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
something saved, i.e. (abstractly) deliverance; hence, aid, victory, prosperity

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative

4.brief: to mar (especially by breaking); figuratively, to split the ears (with sound), i.e. shout (for alarm or joy)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
properly, to creak (or emit a stridulous sound), i.e. to shout (usually for joy)
play upon it; to make music, accompanied by the voice; hence to celebrate in song and music

5.brief: play upon it; to make music, accompanied by the voice; hence to celebrate in song and music
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a musical piece or song to be accompanied by an instrument

6.brief: a trumpet (from its sundered or quavering note)
a cornet (as giving a clear sound) or curved horn
to mar (especially by breaking); figuratively, to split the ears (with sound), i.e. shout (for alarm or joy)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God

7.brief: to tumble, i.e. be violently agitated; specifically, to crash (of thunder); figuratively, to irritate (with anger)

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south
the earth (as moist and therefore inhabited); by extension, the globe; by implication, its inhabitants; specifically, a particular land, as Babylonia, Palestine
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry

8.brief: a stream (including the sea; expectation the Nile, Euphrates, etc.); figuratively, prosperity
to rub or strike the hands together (in exultation)
the hollow hand or palm (so of the paw of an animal, of the sole, and even of the bowl of a dish or sling, the handle of a bolt, the leaves of a palm-tree); figuratively, power
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
properly, to creak (or emit a stridulous sound), i.e. to shout (usually for joy)

9.brief: the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)
the earth (as moist and therefore inhabited); by extension, the globe; by implication, its inhabitants; specifically, a particular land, as Babylonia, Palestine
the right (natural, moral or legal); also (abstractly) equity or (figuratively) prosperity
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
evenness, i.e. (figuratively) prosperity or concord; also straightness, i.e. (figuratively) rectitude (only in plural with singular sense; often adverbially)
